paragraphs.text:
import pandas as pd
import os

os.getcwd()

#We import the news from different sources
path_news =  '/home/ingrid/Documents/DA_Ironhack/Week3/Project-Week-3-Data-Thieves/your-project/In_tests/topics_news_v2.csv'
news = pd.read_csv(path_news, index_col = 0)
news['date_new'] = pd.to_datetime(news['date_published'])
news['date_new'] = news['date_new'].dt.date
#We import the sources where news have been found 
path_sources = '/home/ingrid/Documents/DA_Ironhack/Week3/Project-Week-3-Data-Thieves/your-project/In_tests/newsAPISources.csv'
source = pd.read_csv(path_sources, index_col = 0)
path_refugees = '/home/ingrid/Documents/DA_Ironhack/Week3/Project-Week-3-Data-Thieves/your-project/In_tests/refugees_cleaned_ev_WBD.csv'
refugees = pd.read_csv(path_refugees, index_col = 0)
refugees.columns = ['country_name', 'country_code', 'year', 'number_refugees']
#refugees.head()

%md
# Refugees' topic impact on news and Social Media

*Authors: Alberto Abreu, Josep Foradada and Íngrid Munné*

This paper is the result of the third project under the Data Analytics Bootcamp program at Ironhack Barcelona. In this project, we wanted to work on a topic that really motivated us to keep researching, learning, and furthermore, growing as data analysts but also as human-beings. Refugees is a topic that we are seeing both on social media and on mass-media, but there are some open questions that will be answered in this report. 

The structure of the paper is as follows. First, we will introduce the topic, analyzing the evolution of refugee population by year and by country. We describe the databases we have used to perform the analysis in Section 2.  Later on, we will raise our questions in terms of data analysis based on this topic. Results and conclusions for each question will be provided in Section 4. Then, general conclusions from our analysis will be presented as well as the open questions that can still be researched. 

Structure: 
1. Introduction to the topic. What's the evolution of refugees on social media and newspapers?
2. Questions to be answered
3. Methodology
    * Analysis on twitter
    * Analysis on newspaper

msg.data:
Refugees’ topic impact on news and Social Media

Authors: Alberto Abreu, Josep Foradada and Íngrid Munné

This paper is the result of the third project under the Data Analytics Bootcamp program at Ironhack Barcelona. In this project, we wanted to work on a topic that really motivated us to keep researching, learning, and furthermore, growing as data analysts but also as human-beings. Refugees is a topic that we are seeing both on social media and on mass-media, but there are some open questions that will be answered in this report.

The structure of the paper is as follows. First, we will introduce the topic, analyzing the evolution of refugee population by year and by country. We describe the databases we have used to perform the analysis in Section 2. Later on, we will raise our questions in terms of data analysis based on this topic. Results and conclusions for each question will be provided in Section 4. Then, general conclusions from our analysis will be presented as well as the open questions that can still be researched.

Structure:
1. Introduction to the topic. What’s the evolution of refugees on social media and newspapers?
2. Questions to be answered
3. Methodology
* Analysis on twitter
* Analysis on newspaper

paragraphs.text:
#Title of the project
    #Introduction to your project.
    #Data you are using (and comments, main challenges, strengths & weaknesses, etc...)
    #Questions you want to answer (maybe divided by different topics). Each question should include a graph and a conclusion written in a markdown cell.
    #Conclusions after your analysis.
    #Further questions.

msg.data:
1. Introduction

The term Refugee is defined by the Oxford Dictionary as:

a person who has escaped grom their own country for political, religious, or economic reasons because of a war or political conflict.

This is a topic that we can see and read on social media and also on newspaper. However, are we talking about all the refugees that are in the world? Is this equally covered both in social media and in Twitter. When we started working on the topic, we proposed two main questions:

  • What’s the impact of social important events in media (newspaper) and social media (Twitter)
  • Once the event is raised, is there an equal coverage on Twitter and on newspaper?
    • By total amount of information
    • By timeperiod

Before answering the questions, we wanted to dive deeper into the refugee population around the world, to quantify the situation and understand the problem out there.

paragraphs.text:
%md 
## 1. Introduction
The term Refugee is defined by the Oxford Dictionary as: 

>a person who has escaped grom their own country for political, religious, or economic reasons because of a war or  political conflict. 

This is a topic that we can see and read on social media and also on newspaper. However, are we talking about all the refugees that are in the world? Is this equally covered both in social media and in Twitter. When we started working on the topic, we proposed two main questions: 

- What's the impact of social important events in media (newspaper) and social media (Twitter)
- Once the event is raised, is there an equal coverage on Twitter and on newspaper? 

    * By total amount of information 
    * By timeperiod 
    
Before answering the questions, we wanted to dive deeper into the refugee population around the world, to quantify the situation and understand the problem out there.

paragraphs.title: Fig. 1 - Refugee population by year
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT year, sum(number_refugees) AS number_of_refugees from refugees GROUP BY year

paragraphs.text:
%md
As can be seen from the Figure 1, there is a clear growth on the total amount of refugees since 2012, that has been nearly doubled the value in 2010. 

According to the information provided from World Bank Data, the countries were the most amount of refugees are the following ones: Syrian Arab Republic, Afghanistan, South Sudan, Myanmar, Somalia, Sudan, Democratic Republic of Congo, Central African Republic, Eritrea and Burundi. We want to take a look at this data to see if this is a topic that should be clearly spoken in our daily-lives (Figure 2). Hence, we can see that there is a tr

paragraphs.title: Fig. 2 - Refugee population by country of origin

paragraphs.text:
%md
### 1.1. Databases Used
In order to develop this project, several databases have been used. First of all, Twitter API to get the tweets on this topic. Secondly, NewsAPI has been used as a source to get news from newspapers and digital newspapers. Later on, web scraping on diferent webpages has been performed to get data on Google Search and OnlineNewspaperlist.com. Finally, in order to have a common background on the topic, we wanted to analyse the number of refugees in the world in order to know how huge this political problem is all over the world. Data has been taken from WorldBank Data. 
These databases have several limitations and restrictions that should be considered beforehand, and that had also supposed some challenges to our project. 

- NewsAPI
    This API contains different limitations if you don't pay fror premium permisions.
    It retrieves data from past two months. 
    Furthermore, it only retrieves 5 pages for each topic you insert as a parameter. 
    The API has a source dataset that can be retrieved and then labeded. However, this API looks for data in sources that are not included in the source dataset. 
    
- World Bank Data 
    There are some gaps in the datasets, meaning that there is only only data from 1991 onwards. 
    There are some aggregated countries or areas that bias the final results and requires a careful data cleaning before performing any analysis. 


- Twitter API 


- Google Search 



- OnlineNewspaperlist.com

msg.data:
1.1. Databases Used

In order to develop this project, several databases have been used. First of all, Twitter API to get the tweets on this topic. Secondly, NewsAPI has been used as a source to get news from newspapers and digital newspapers. Later on, web scraping on diferent webpages has been performed to get data on Google Search and OnlineNewspaperlist.com. Finally, in order to have a common background on the topic, we wanted to analyse the number of refugees in the world in order to know how huge this political problem is all over the world. Data has been taken from WorldBank Data.
These databases have several limitations and restrictions that should be considered beforehand, and that had also supposed some challenges to our project.

  • NewsAPI
    This API contains different limitations if you don’t pay fror premium permisions.
    It retrieves data from past two months.
    Furthermore, it only retrieves 5 pages for each topic you insert as a parameter.
    The API has a source dataset that can be retrieved and then labeded. However, this API looks for data in sources that are not included in the source dataset.

  • World Bank Data
    There are some gaps in the datasets, meaning that there is only only data from 1991 onwards.
    There are some aggregated countries or areas that bias the final results and requires a careful data cleaning before performing any analysis.

  • Twitter API

  • Google Search

  • OnlineNewspaperlist.com

paragraphs.text:
%md 
## Refugees coverage on news

If we take a look at the data coming from NewsAPI, we can see that there are some periods where more news on this topic. However, t

SELECT date_new, source_id, count(title) FROM news GROUP BY source_id

paragraphs.title: Fig.2 - Total news published on the past three weeks

paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT  source.source_id,  source.name, count(news.source_id) AS total_news FROM news LEFT JOIN source ON news.source_id = source.source_id GROUP BY news.source_id ORDER BY total_news DESC LIMIT 10
